results.headline: A Nightmare on a Ski Lift
results.summary_short: A minimalist setup delivers maximum fright in “Frozen,” a nifty little chiller that balances its cold terrain with an unexpectedly warm heart.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Frozen

results.headline: Passion and Identity Crisis in a Pious Community
results.summary_short: “Eyes Wide Open” explores the conflict between sexual desire and religious obligation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Eyes Wide Open

results.headline: Men and Terror Run Wild
results.summary_short: The blood that runs through the “Red Riding” trilogy begins as a river that races and then rages until it floods this dank, dark, pitiless world in misery.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 1974: The Red Riding Trilogy Part 1

results.headline: Americans Spark the Gunfire in the City of Light
results.summary_short: “From Paris With Love,” starring John Travolta and Jonathan Rhys Meyers, is really a one-sided buddy movie.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of From Paris With Love

results.headline: A Latino Bronx Tale
results.summary_short: “Falling Awake” puts good intentions and appealing performances into the balance against clichés of dead-end neighborhoods and rebellious youth.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Falling Awake

results.headline: Bouncing and Soaring, With Mayhem in Mind
results.summary_short: “District 13: Ultimatum” is pleasurable nonsense and another reminder that one of the great pulls of cinema is the spectacle of bodies in blissful motion.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of District 13: Ultimatum

results.headline: Young Love Caught in the Grips of 9/11
results.summary_short: “Dear John” may not be strong medicine, but it delivers an effective, pleasing dose of pure sentiment and vicarious heartache.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dear John

results.headline: An Israeli Tale of Communal Mistrust, Without the Finger-Pointing
results.summary_short: One of the pleasures of “Ajami” is its deep immersion in the beats and melodies of everyday life in Jaffa and beyond.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ajami

results.headline: ‘Because It’s There’ Is the Least of Their Reasons
results.summary_short: As you watch Philipp Stölzl’s gripping survival drama, “North Face,” it is impossible not to put yourself in the boots of its mountaineers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of North Face

results.headline: Coins and a Fountain That Make a Magic Mess
results.summary_short: “When in Rome” fails to produce anything much in the way of worthwhile complication.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of When in Rome

results.headline: Poor Insurance Adjuster Has a Devil of a Problem
results.summary_short: “Saint John of Las Vegas” is a pretentious indie road comedy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Saint John of Las Vegas

results.headline: A Race for Identity
results.summary_short: “Do you feel black?” is a question that hovers subliminally over every scene in “Off and Running.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Off and Running

results.headline: He’s Older and a Cuckold, but He Has Tough Friends
results.summary_short: “44-Inch Chest” can be described as six guys sitting around in barely furnished rooms, talking.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 44 Inch Chest

results.headline: Tale of a Terrorist
results.summary_short: A Palestinian terrorist and an Israeli outcast lock fates in “For My Father.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of For My Father

results.headline: Jaw-Breaking Boston Detective Unravels His Daughter’s Murder
results.summary_short: Mel Gibson tries a return to movie-star form in “Edge of Darkness.”

results.headline: A Singer Who Stopped His Showing Off
results.summary_short: Much of the biographical documentary “Still Bill,” about the singer Bill Withers, is pleasant and even moving.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Still Bill

results.headline: Diner Serves Apocalypse, Easy on the Destruction
results.summary_short: In “Legion” the world ends not with a bang but with a short stack.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Legion

results.headline: An Athlete in Search of Redemption
results.summary_short: “To Save a Life” would be a mere nuisance if not for its shameless exploitation of school shootings to advance its agenda.

results.headline: Nonbelievers Must Wear Tutus
results.summary_short: In “Tooth Fairy,” Dwayne Johnson, a k a the Rock, shows once again that he has no real acting talent.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tooth Fairy

results.headline: Documentary of the Civil Rights Movement, Arranged and Composed for Gen Y
results.summary_short: The documentary “Soundtrack for a Revolution” is essentially a condensed, lightly airbrushed, skillfully assembled history of the civil rights movement.
